headline.main: Excerpts from commentary on Long Island

docs.abstract: In Other Words column; excerpt from Times of Huntington commentary supports Long Island school districts that are asking teachers to pick up more of their health insurance costs; excerpt from Michael A Levy commentary in Glen Cove Record Pilot scores low voter turnout in Glen Cove, NY
docs.section_name: Health; New York and Region; Opinion

docs.lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa - As they campaigned in western Iowa today, two Democratic presidential rivals gently tangled over their health care plans, with Senator Barack Obama drawing criticism from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton after suggesting his plan would cut costs and help consumers more "than any other proposal in this race."

headline.main: Obama and Clinton Tangle Over Health Care

docs.abstract: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton traded fire on health care, which voters say is one of the leading issues on their minds this year.
docs.snippet: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton traded fire on health care, which voters say is one of the leading issues on their minds this year.

byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE AND KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who was fired from a job working for Macomb County after less than 10 days was kept on the government-paid health insurance plan for eight years, billing $230,000 for treatment of cancer and other ailments, a prosecutor says. The prosecutor, Eric Smith, of Macomb County filed four counts of health care fraud against the woman, Jackie Youhanian, 38, who now lives at Prattville, Ala. She was removed from the county payroll at the Martha T. Berry Medical Facility in Mount Clemens, but apparently not the health care rolls, a mistake officials say may have been a record-keeping error. “This was not a one-time error, or a goof-up, or a mistake in judgment,” Mr. Smith said in a news release. “This was a continuing criminal scheme.” Ms. Youhanian did not immediately return calls to her home seeking comment.
